data.title: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph
data.meta_description: MemphisTigers.org:  The #1 Board for Memphis Tigers sports on the internet.
data.text:
Post: #7

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 10:14 AM)benaroundtiger Wrote: I love it! I mean lets be honest...none of us thought that Zack would turn out to be the player he has been. He has been a top 3 power forward in the league and in my opinion the 4 spot is the most important in the NBA.

Before the season started Verno and Herrington were going over all of the preseason publications' predictions and I remember there was a sole publication that predicted the Grizzlies would win 45 games due in large part to the addition of Z-Bo.

I cannot remember the publication but I want to say it was Basketball Prospectus. They were the only ones that foresaw the Grizzlies success.

Post: #8

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 11:49 AM)the other Greg Childers Wrote: Adding a 20/10 guy to the weakest spot in the starting lineup was going to have some positive effect.

Much more than any of us realized at the time. Nobody was predicting we'd be in 7th in the West before the All-Star break.

It's not just that he's getting 20 and 10, he's doing it more efficiently than he's done it anywhere else (primarily by limiting his outside shots).

(This post was last modified: 01-28-2010 01:26 PM by Briskbas.)

Post: #12

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 02:38 PM)homefry20 Wrote: Its not the on court ability and statistics that has surprised me but rather his ability to be a role model and develop some of the younger players into a cohesive unit. He has done wonders for Gasol especially with interior passing and rebounding. Thats the biggest surprise of it all.

This is the major shocker. All anyone needs to know about Randolph is that there were absolutely no other takers for someone who averages 20 and 10.

Post: #13

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 03:16 PM)Stammers Wrote:

(01-28-2010 02:38 PM)homefry20 Wrote: Its not the on court ability and statistics that has surprised me but rather his ability to be a role model and develop some of the younger players into a cohesive unit. He has done wonders for Gasol especially with interior passing and rebounding. Thats the biggest surprise of it all.

This is the major shocker. All anyone needs to know about Randolph is that there were absolutely no other takers for someone who averages 20 and 10.

Not sure if anyone else was interested in 2009 but in 2008, I clearly remember the Nuggets, Bulls and Cavs expressing interest in acquiring Z-Bo. Headcase or not, 20-10 guys are hard to come by and he's still a young guy with at least 4-5 more yrs of productive playing time at his position.

Post: #14

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 03:21 PM)tiger1016 Wrote:

(01-28-2010 03:16 PM)Stammers Wrote:

(01-28-2010 02:38 PM)homefry20 Wrote: Its not the on court ability and statistics that has surprised me but rather his ability to be a role model and develop some of the younger players into a cohesive unit. He has done wonders for Gasol especially with interior passing and rebounding. Thats the biggest surprise of it all.

This is the major shocker. All anyone needs to know about Randolph is that there were absolutely no other takers for someone who averages 20 and 10.

Not sure if anyone else was interested in 2009 but in 2008, I clearly remember the Nuggets, Bulls and Cavs expressing interest in acquiring Z-Bo. Headcase or not, 20-10 guys are hard to come by and he's still a young guy with at least 4-5 more yrs of productive playing time at his position.

Yep. Supposedly, Karl pushed hard for the Nuggets to get him. He knew he could have helped them out a lot.

Post: #17

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 01:08 PM)Stumpbuster Wrote:

(01-28-2010 10:14 AM)benaroundtiger Wrote: I love it! I mean lets be honest...none of us thought that Zack would turn out to be the player he has been. He has been a top 3 power forward in the league and in my opinion the 4 spot is the most important in the NBA.

Before the season started Verno and Herrington were going over all of the preseason publications' predictions and I remember there was a sole publication that predicted the Grizzlies would win 45 games due in large part to the addition of Z-Bo.

I cannot remember the publication but I want to say it was Basketball Prospectus. They were the only ones that foresaw the Grizzlies success.

That is correct - they are looking pretty prophetic now aren't they?

Post: #18

RE: Geoff Calkins was wrong about Zach Randolph

(01-28-2010 04:01 PM)jtgavigan Wrote:

(01-28-2010 01:08 PM)Stumpbuster Wrote:

(01-28-2010 10:14 AM)benaroundtiger Wrote: I love it! I mean lets be honest...none of us thought that Zack would turn out to be the player he has been. He has been a top 3 power forward in the league and in my opinion the 4 spot is the most important in the NBA.

Before the season started Verno and Herrington were going over all of the preseason publications' predictions and I remember there was a sole publication that predicted the Grizzlies would win 45 games due in large part to the addition of Z-Bo.

I cannot remember the publication but I want to say it was Basketball Prospectus. They were the only ones that foresaw the Grizzlies success.

That is correct - they are looking pretty prophetic now aren't they?

Thanks for the knowledge on that article, bentiger, I will have to look it up and see what the Basketball Prospectus predicted the Memphis Grizzlies to win forty-five games this season with the addition of power forward Zach Randolph to the team.

(This post was last modified: 01-28-2010 06:45 PM by BARTLETTTIGER.)
